texts.definition: Game elements that hinder players from taking the shortest route between two places in game worlds.
markups: <style="Definition">Game elements that hinder players from taking the shortest route between two places in game worlds.</style>

One definition of playing a game is "the voluntary attempt to overcome unnecessary obstacles". This can be applied literally by requiring that navigation in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> take into consideration diegetically present physical <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style>. Often the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> may be moved, destroyed, or avoided by specific actions but until this has been done (and it has become possible to do so), the Obstacles slow or block the players' progress in the game.

A typical kind of <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> are locked doors that require keys of various kinds. Examples of games that have this include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leisure%20Suit%20Larry%20series">Leisure Suit Larry series</link></style>.

Walls are <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> to both movement and laser firing in the board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style>. It also stops movement in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style> but here this can be advantageous since the robots cannot stop in any other way, and choosing the right walls (and other robots) to collide with is the only way to reach the goal destinations.

Most of the problems in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal%20series">Portal series</link></style> include finding ways of moving past obstacles by manipulating game objects and creating "portals" between different parts of levels. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Faction%20series">Red Faction series</link></style> also contain <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> in the form of walls, floors, and ceilings but these can be destroyed by players to give new access routes. In contrast, the board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> begins with no <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> to player movement in a space ship, but these can occur as effects of damage.

<style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> are most often created by making sufficiently large <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>. These may any type of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, but <style="Link"><link="cosmetic-game-items">Cosmetic Game Items</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> are examples that will be primarily experienced as <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> since they have little or no other effects on gameplay. <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> are worth pointing out in that they are naturally immobile while <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> are also worth pointing since they are highly mobile. A weaker form <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style>, where the shortest route can still be taken but is not as efficient as taking a circumstantial route, can be created by <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> that give <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>; using <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style> provide weaker examples still since they do not actually hinder <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> but make passing through them into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations. <style="Link"><link="invisible-walls">Invisible Walls</link></style> are also <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> but these may not even be noticed by players if they follow the routes intended by game designers. While <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> can be used in any type of areas, they can in general challenge players more in <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style> since higher speed are likely there.

The choice of <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> determines how players can bypass it, if at all. <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> that lets players ignore them while still maintaining their status as <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> to others. Making them <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> provides players with options of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style> by <style="Link"><link="damage">Damaging</link></style> them - being able to do this can be a form of <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>. However, any kind of <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Object</link></style> can result in <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> being created when it is destroyed, so the two patterns can be used to modify each other. Having <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style> as <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> make bypassing them a question of waiting or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style> can be <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> they can also be modulated by <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> if they can be used to change the movement direction of the <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>, and this creates a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirect%20Control">Indirect Control</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> that are <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style> blocking the way to <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> are often linked to <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> that can remove them; the <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> can either simply be <style="Link"><link="switches">Switches</link></style> that need to be found or be game elements that need specific <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> (e.g. keys or key cards). Another option is to give players <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> to ignore the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style>. If the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> can be removed by players that have reached the far side of them, the <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style> provide a way to create <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style>.

Typically, <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> that do not act as boundaries for <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> can be avoided by taking longer routes, even if it is simply walking around a boulder or tree. Note that <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> can also be a large areas, for example mountains or chasms. While <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> affect how <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can move in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can be <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> to each other if they are <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> are usually not deadly to <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, but can be so when colliding with them can cause <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>.

While blocking access to areas or creating detours are probably the most common reasons for placing <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, but they can also be placed to create <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style> simply by making these areas more difficult to notice.

<style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style> have a complex relation to <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style>. Having them present from the beginning can invalidate the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> as hindering <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, but letting players open or create the <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style> during gameplay, as is the characteristic gameplay mechanic in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal%20series">Portal series</link></style>, provide the necessary building blocks for creating a spatial form of <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>.

If <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> are placed so they only become apparent when they are close, typically through a combination of high speed and turning corners, they give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>.

In games building their gameplay extensively on <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> are sometimes used as diegetic game elements that provide collisions between them and the players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> as thematic explanations for the failures.

<style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> create <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style> in how <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can perform <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. They can also affect <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> since they can block <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> if they are not transparent, and this can make places with a view over the area worse as <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style> while making the places themselves better as <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style>. They can also force players to perform <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style> since they may not be able to see the areas they are moving into (this most often occurs with <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jumping">Jumping</link></style> or teleporting instead of "ordinary" <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>). The <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> that are created by <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> and that provide <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> do instead raise <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations. By having these effects, they naturally are <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> even if this can be enhanced by their visual presentation. Depending on the size of the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style>, they can also make <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> difficult simply because they can make it difficult to get an overview of one's surroundings. By using these features and being placed strategically, <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> can modulate <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> to offer <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> by creating <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>. When the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> block the <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style> rather than define them but can be removed in some fashion, this instead creates <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals if the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> are <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>. Intentionally or not, <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> can create <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style> by occluding them.

While all <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> are <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, the reverse is not true since some game items can be stepped over or onto, or can easily be moved aside. <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> can be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> if they appear suddenly from the players' perspective. When happens, they can effectively be <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> if collisions can cause <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> or provide other negative effects. If their appearance are <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style>, they can enforce <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/One-Way%20Travel">One-Way Travel</link></style> through making retracing ones steps impossible.

Skillful players may be able to bypass more than one <style="CurrentLink">Obstacle</style> at the same time or without requiring more <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> than if the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> were not present. This is an expression of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> made possible by, depending on the nature of the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style>, players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> their actions (e.g. moving between moving objects), them performing <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style> (e.g. avoiding stationary objects and other vehicles when driving), or by succeeding with <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> (e.g. finding the most cost efficient route).

Non-transparent <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> in a game since players or <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> can be hindered from knowing what happens behind the <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style>. This also makes <style="CurrentLink">Obstacles</style> basic building elements for <style="Link"><link="hiding-places">Hiding Places</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hiding-places">Hiding Places</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cosmetic-game-items">Cosmetic Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="invisible-walls">Invisible Walls</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style>
